Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Migration and State Regulation in the Wake of Economic Crisis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
People's ability to move is highly regulated, though often in ways they are unaware of: vehicle registration, licenses, IDs, passports, permits, policing, stop signs, the tarring of roads, etc. But economic and political crises can suddenly harden these forms of regulation. How are people's conceptions of mobility, governance, and citizenship expressed and transformed in the face of constant and immediate regulation? This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, scientifically grounded fieldwork, examines what factors contribute to effective citizen/state relations and governance in the wake of economic crisis.

Stanford University doctoral candidate, Kathryn Takabvirwa, under the supervision of Dr. James Ferguson, will explore how regulators and regulated navigate government regulatory projects designed to restrict mobility following an economic crisis. Zimbabwe presents an ideal site for the nexus of citizenship and legality in the context of migration. The country is emerging from exceptional economic crisis which saw its inflation hit over 89 sextillion percent in 2008, and where a staggering 10% to 42% of the population exited the country and migrates regularly between Zimbabwe and neighboring countries like South Africa. Issues of global concern in an era of hyper-mobility are accentuated in such contexts. The researcher will explore these questions through a 13-month ethnographic study. Taking a multi-methods approach, the project uses both qualitative and quantitative data, employing participant observation, in-depth interviews, survey methods, archival work and material analysis. This study contributes to a better, more nuanced understanding of experiences in post-crisis societies. It advances understandings of how citizenship and sociality are forged in the spaces of citizen/state engagement in everyday life. It goes beyond conventional approaches that see developing countries as simply mired in corruption to empirically examine how policies and practices are actually experienced, and present a more nuanced understanding of citizenship and governance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: This project examines policing in Zimbabwe, in the wake of staggering economic and sociopolitical crisis. In 2008, Zimbabwe’s inflation hit a record high of 89,700,000,000,000,000,000,000%, and estimates ranging between 10% and 42% of the population left the country, many migrating regularly between Zimbabwe and neighboring South Africa. The creation of a circulatory population, together with a radical informalization of the country’s economy, triggered an explosion of official police roadblocks throughout the country and heightened policing, especially on the road. This project examines encounters at roadblocks, and through that, broader experiences of mobility and policing in Zimbabwe.

Methodology: I conducted 15 months of ethnographic fieldwork in Zimbabwe, from June 2014 to September 2015, during which I did participant observation along the roads, at police stations, government offices, and other mobility-relevant spaces, conducted interviews, and carried out a survey with local residents. As anthropologists often do, I engaged in everyday practices with residents of my field site: lining up to fetch water or apply for passports, driving to collect children from school, etc. to understand policing within the broader systems of governance and social life in Zimbabwe. I am currently analyzing and writing up the findings from this research. In the analysis of ethnographic work, writing is a part of the analytical process more so than a means of representing pre-analyzed data; writing and analysis occur in tandem as iterative processes. Thus, findings from the study are still in formulation. 

Outcomes, Merit and Broader Impact: This project contributes to a fuller understanding of state officials in Africa, and of citizenship, in the governance of movement. The project advances an “empirical basis” for theorizing the state (Gupta 1995; Mbembe 1992) and how both the police and those they police see themselves in relation to the state project. It elaborates on analytics for understanding governance in Africa, particularly with regard to state ‘failure.’ It does so by considering the ways success and failure are actually experienced in the everyday by those engaged in and affected by the state project. It finds that although roadblocks are a form of and contribute to both regular and spectacular forms of violence, they simultaneously operate as sites for engagement, for pushing back, and speaking back. Migration, governance and citizen/state relations are of central importance not only in scholarship but also in the lived experience of governance in nation-states. This project contributes to understandings of these in four ways. Firstly, it examines the experiences and governance of internal movement, where it is neither rural-urban migration nor that of internally displaced persons (IDPs). This is a critical yet under-studied aspect of migration in sub-Saharan Africa, as internal migration is “rendered invisible” through the ways categories of analysis are defined (Lubkemann 2008; Polzer 2008). Secondly, it brings the governance of movement in which police and policed are both legal citizens into the analytical frame. Examining cases where police and policed do not stand as ‘citizen’ and ‘alien’ respectively allows for a deeper engagement with the delineation of membership, ideas about personhoods and rights to place and passage. Thirdly, frameworks for police/policed exchanges in the Global South often characterize them as rent-seeking patron-client relationships, understanding them in terms of bribery and as evidence of corruption.
